title: Dating apps like Tinder and Grindr linked to reports of rape and grooming
title_page: Dating apps like Tinder and Grindr linked to reports of rape and grooming | Daily Mail Online
text:
Crime: Police say reports involving dating apps like Tinder have risen sevenfold in just two years – and include serious offences such as rape, assault and child exploitation
Crime reports involving dating apps have risen sevenfold in just two years – and include serious offences such as rape, assault and child exploitation.
Just 55 cases were recorded by police in England and Wales in 2013, but this soared to 412 last year.
The figures have prompted calls for app users to be better educated about the dangers of meeting people online, amid fears they are ‘just the tip of the iceberg’.
‘If we are going to base the formation of a relationship on a photo and a few lines of text, how do we know that person is who they say they are?’ said Andy Phippen, a professor of digital responsibility at Plymouth University.
‘It is something we tell children about – don’t trust who people say they are online – but adults go merrily about thinking it is a good way of [finding a partner].’
The figures have been revealed through the Freedom of Information Act, which is under threat from the Government. Ministers claim it is ‘too costly’ to administer and have ordered a review.
Some 30 police forces responded to the request, which showed that two years ago there were just 21 crime reports involving the dating app Tinder, compared with 277 in 2015. Meanwhile Grindr saw numbers rise from 34 in 2013 to 135 last year.
Tinder is hugely popular among heterosexual daters with around 50million users worldwide, while Grindr is a gay dating app.
Reports of aggression and sexual crimes were the most common, with 253 allegations of violence and 152 of offences such as rape, grooming and sexual exploitation of children.
The figures come from police reports where the apps are mentioned and does not automatically mean they were used directly by the alleged criminal.
However there have been documented cases in which they were used.
Deputy Chief Constable Andy Cooke, head of public protection for the National Police Chiefs’ Council, blamed the rise in crime reports on the apps’ growing popularity.
He also warned users to be careful about who they contact. ‘I would urge those who use online dating apps to be as security conscious as possible,’ he said. ‘[They should] not share personal data until they are sure about who they are communicating with.’
Stranger danger: Deputy Chief Constable Andy Cooke warned users not to share personal data until they are sure about who they are communicating with
Human rights campaigner Peter Tatchell said: ‘The steep rise in sexual and violent offences is a worrying trend that seems likely to continue. I suspect these figures are just the tip of the iceberg.’
Meanwhile the NSPCC warned that children are in danger if they use the apps.
A spokesman said: ‘Dating apps are not safe for children. It’s easy for children to say they are older, or for adults to pretend to be younger.’
In September, former teacher Gary Pearce from Sidcup, Kent, was given a five-year jail sentence for grooming a 14-year-old boy he met on Grindr.
